devotional_title: Immanuel: The Lord Who Comes in Prophecy and Word
brief_devotional: The Advent season initiates a time to consider the prophecies of Christ. This passage records God giving the sign to the house of David: a virgin shall conceive and bear a son, naming him Immanuel, which means "God with us." This promise points directly to the lowly coming of Christ in the flesh, which the Church commemorates at Christmas.
short_prayer: O Lord Jesus, Thou hast again entered into our midst by granting unto us the proclamation of Thy Word. Grant us grace to welcome Thee aright, lest through sin, vanity, and unbelief we drive Thee away from us. Amen.

devotional_title: The Great Light and the Prince of Peace
brief_devotional: This reading speaks of the great light shining on those dwelling in darkness and the shadow of death, referring directly to the light brought by the coming King. This child, whose birth brings joy, is identified by the glorious titles: Wonderful, Counsellor, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace. His kingdom is established with justice and righteousness forever.
short_prayer: Lord Jesus Christ, our King, grant us to be joyful as we await Thy coming, that we may be freed from the darkness of our sins and established in the righteousness of Thy peace. Amen.

devotional_title: The Prophet Who Blesses Through Repentance
brief_devotional: Advent reminds us to receive Christ as the Prophet foretold by Moses and the ancient prophets. Peter here proclaims that God sent His Son Jesus, having raised Him up, to bless you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities. This turning away from sin highlights the need for repentance during this preparatory season.
short_prayer: Almighty God, merciful Father, grant us grace to heed Thy Son, the great Prophet, that we may turn from our iniquities and receive the blessing of salvation. Amen.

devotional_title: The Majesty of Christ and Reconciliation by the Cross
brief_devotional: This reading reveals the majesty of Christ, the focus of Advent. He is described as the image of the invisible God and the Creator by whom all things consist. His coming into the world, commemorated during this season, was to reconcile all things through the blood of His cross, drawing us who were once alienated back into peace with God.
short_prayer: We pray, O Lord, that we may hold fast to Thy Son, the image of Thy glory, and constantly rejoice that through His cross we are now reconciled unto Thee. Amen.

devotional_title: God Has Spoken by His Glorious Son
brief_devotional: God, who at sundry times and in divers manners spake in times past unto the fathers by the prophets, hath in these last days spoken unto us by His Son. This Son, superior to angels, is the brightness of His glory, who, after purging our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high. This confirms Christ's continual presence and power, central to the celebration of Advent.
short_prayer: O Lord God, Whose Son is the express image of Thy person, grant that we may heed His voice, that we may receive the glorious light of the Gospel. Amen.

devotional_title: Giving Earnest Heed to Great Salvation
brief_devotional: Having heard the declaration of Christ's glory, we are admonished to give more earnest heed to the great salvation He delivered. This salvation, confirmed by God through signs and wonders, is delivered through His Word and Sacraments. Advent calls us to vigilantly prepare for the coming Judge, emphasizing that the remaining time is short.
short_prayer: O Lord, mercifully hear our prayer and stretch forth Thy right hand to defend us from falling away from the great salvation delivered by Thy Son. Amen.

devotional_title: Relying Solely on God's Grace, Not the Law
brief_devotional: The rich young ruler sought eternal life by keeping the commandments—the Law always accuses and terrifies the conscience, and does not justify. Jesus reveals that salvation requires giving up all and is impossible by human effort, illustrating that making ready the way of the Lord requires a complete reliance on God’s grace.
short_prayer: We confess, O Lord, that we are burdened by guilt and cannot save ourselves. Deliver us from the curse of the Law, and grant us grace to rely solely on the treasures of Thy mercy. Amen.

devotional_title: Stir Up Our Hearts for the God of Hope
brief_devotional: (Second Sunday in Advent) The Scriptures were written aforetime for our learning, that through patience and comfort we might have hope. This hope is essential during Advent as we wait for Christ, who came to confirm the promises made to the fathers and bring glory to God by reconciling both Jew and Gentile.
short_prayer: Stir up our hearts, O Lord, to make ready the way of Thine only-begotten Son, so that by His coming we may be enabled to serve Thee with pure minds. Amen.

devotional_title: Preaching the Gospel as Chief Worship
brief_devotional: Jesus publicly announces His purpose by reading from the prophet Isaiah, declaring: "The Spirit of the Lord is upon me... to preach the gospel to the poor." This demonstrates that the preaching of the gospel is the chief worship of God. Christ's coming is primarily revealed and delivered through the proclamation of His Word.
short_prayer: O Lord, our heavenly Father, mighty and everlasting God, grant that I may gladly hear Thy Word and that all my worship may be acceptable unto Thee; through Jesus Christ, my Lord. Amen.

devotional_title: The Call to Repentance and Contrite Hearts
brief_devotional: Jesus calls Levi and then eats with sinners and tax collectors. His defense: "I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance." Advent is a penitential season, and this passage stresses that Christ's coming is aimed entirely at calling those afflicted by a feeling of guilt to repentance and sure comfort.
short_prayer: O Lord Jesus Christ, grant us to be new and contrite hearts, that we may acknowledge our wretchedness and find perfect remission and forgiveness in Thee. Amen.

devotional_title: Praying for Faithful Teachers in the Ministry
brief_devotional: Before choosing His twelve apostles, Jesus spent the entire night in prayer to God. The Office of the Ministry is fundamental to the church, as God’s gifts are delivered through the Word and Sacraments administered by those authorized for the task. We must pray for faithful teachers to proclaim the blessed Gospel.
short_prayer: Almighty God, who calledst men to Thy service, give unto Thy Church evermore faithful teachers to proclaim the glory of Thy name. Amen.

devotional_title: Be Merciful, as Your Father is Merciful
brief_devotional: Jesus teaches us to be merciful, as your Father also is merciful, and warns against judging others. The Christian life flows from God's mercy; we must always turn our focus from ourselves and our efforts to the clear priority on the means of grace.
short_prayer: O Lord, Whose tender mercy grants us pardon, help us to show forth mercy and charity to all men, that we may avoid the pitfall of self-righteous judgment. Amen.

devotional_title: The Power of the Word and the Centurion’s Faith
brief_devotional: The Centurion's faith is commended because he understood authority and simply trusted Christ's Word, saying, "But say in a word, and my servant shall be healed." Faith is required to receive Christ and His gifts. We are called to receive the promises of God through true faith.
short_prayer: Almighty God, Who calledst the Centurion to faith in Thy Word alone, increase and strengthen our faith, that we may fully rely upon the power of Thy Son's Word. Amen.

devotional_title: John the Baptist: Making Straight the Way
brief_devotional: John the Baptist, whose way the Lord prepared, sends messengers to confirm Christ's identity. John is praised as more than a prophet because his voice was necessary to make straight the way of the Lord. Advent focuses on John's ministry of calling sinners to repentance.
short_prayer: O Lord, grant us Thy grace to put away all worldly affections, and to receive the testimony of Thy prophets, that we may follow Thy Son alone. Amen.

devotional_title: Rejoice: Stewards of the Mysteries
brief_devotional: (Third Sunday in Advent) The theme of the Third Sunday is rejoice. This Epistle teaches that ministers are to be regarded as servants of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God. Our duty is to be found faithful, and we should rejoice not in our own judgment, but in the judgment of the Lord Who shall bring to light the hidden things of darkness.
short_prayer: O God, who dost gladden us with the yearly anticipation of our redemption, grant that we who now joyfully receive Thine only-begotten Son as our Redeemer may also behold Him without fear when He cometh as our Judge; who liveth, etc. Amen.

devotional_title: Touching Christ by Faith
brief_devotional: The woman with the issue of blood pressed through the crowd simply to touch the border of His garment, believing that she would be instantly healed. Christ declares, "Daughter, be of good comfort: thy faith hath made thee whole." This reminds us that Christ's power is delivered to us when we touch Him by faith.
short_prayer: Dear Savior, upon Thy gracious invitation I come to Thine altar. Let me find favor in Thine eyes that I may receive Thy grace to the salvation of our soul. Amen.

devotional_title: Taking Up the Cross Daily and Following Christ
brief_devotional: Jesus tells His disciples: "If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me." The Christian life is a daily battle. We must be patient in tribulation and remember that Christ's death destroyed death and restored us to everlasting life.
short_prayer: O Lord Jesus, make us firm if we waver, strengthen us if we weaken, and help us to take up our cross daily and follow Thee. Amen.

devotional_title: The Transfiguration: Glory and Comfort
brief_devotional: This reading relates the Transfiguration of Christ, a glimpse of the glory that awaits Him. This glory comforts us now as we wait for His coming. It is a reminder that the Lord's exaltation is for our benefit, drawing us to the love of those things which are not seen.
short_prayer: We thank Thee, O God, for revealing the glory of Thy Son, that we may be drawn to the love of those things which are not seen. Amen.

devotional_title: Proclaiming the Kingdom of God Nigh
brief_devotional: Christ sends out seventy disciples, demonstrating His priority for the proclamation of the Gospel. They are instructed to heal the sick and declare: "The kingdom of God is come nigh unto you." The means of grace are the exclusive content of the Church's task.
short_prayer: O Lord, we beseech Thee to bless the labors of Thy ministers, that through the faithful preaching of the Gospel, Thy kingdom may be spread throughout the world. Amen.

devotional_title: Choosing the Good Part: Hearing the Word
brief_devotional: Jesus commends Mary for choosing "that good part, which shall not be taken away from her" by sitting at His feet and hearing His Word. This Advent devotion prepares us by emphasizing that hearing and keeping the Word of God is essential to the Christian life.
short_prayer: Pour out upon us Thy Holy Spirit that He may enlighten us to know what is right, and awaken within us a desire to hear and inwardly digest Thy Word. Amen.

devotional_title: Seeking Wisdom in the Sign of Jonah
brief_devotional: Christ speaks of the sign of Jonah, teaching that the crowds require illumination to understand His identity. The purpose of instruction is to ensure that God's Word is rightly understood and fixed in the memory, leading us to salvation.
short_prayer: O Lord, we beseech Thee, lighten the darkness of our hearts by Thy gracious visitation, and grant us spiritual wisdom to understand the signs of Thy coming. Amen.

devotional_title: Putting Away Lusts for Christ’s Visitation
brief_devotional: (Fourth Sunday in Advent) John the Baptist declares, "I am not the Christ," but only the voice of one crying in the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord. His work, fulfilled in repentance, is essential for preparing the heart for the coming Savior. We must put away fleshly lusts that we may be ready for Christ's visitation.
short_prayer: Most merciful God, who hast given Thine eternal Word to be made incarnate of the pure Virgin, grant unto Thy people grace to put away fleshly lusts that so they may be ready for Thy visitation; through the same Jesus Christ, Thy Son, our Lord, who liveth, etc. Amen.

devotional_title: The Key of Knowledge and Pure Understanding
brief_devotional: Christ condemns the lawyers who took away the key of knowledge, neither entering themselves nor allowing others to enter. This is a sober warning during Advent to seek and promote the pure understanding of the Gospel and the proper administration of the sacraments.
short_prayer: O God, send us Thy Holy Spirit to enlighten us, that we may not be preserved in blindness, but receive salvation. Amen.

devotional_title: Vigilance and Watching for the Son of Man
brief_devotional: (Christmas Eve/Vigil) We are exhorted to be ready also: for the Son of man cometh at an hour when ye think not. Although we celebrate Christ's first, lowly coming tonight, Advent demands that we remain vigilant for His second coming to judge the earth. We must watch and pray constantly.
short_prayer: Lord Jesus, our Watchman, grant us grace constantly to bear in mind that we are sinners, to seek the rich treasures of Thy grace, and to watch and pray without ceasing. Amen.

devotional_title: The Word Made Flesh: Glorifying God
brief_devotional: (Christmas Day, The Feast of the Nativity of Our Lord) The shepherds found the Babe and returned, glorifying and praising God. This day commemorates the mystery of the Word made flesh, the tidings of great joy. The Christian must grasp the high article that the Infant born of Mary is true God, born as a Savior.
short_prayer: Lord Jesus, in these days our hearts overflow with joy, for we call to mind Thy birth, which bringeth salvation. Let the fire of Thy love warm our hearts and kindle therein a sincere love of Thee. Amen.
